Insulin facilitates the uptake of potassium into cells, not outside, contradicting the third option. The half-life of subcutaneous insulin is approximately 5-10 minutes, not 60 minutes, which invalidates the fourth option. Therefore, the only true statement regarding insulin is that it is composed of two polypeptide chains bound by disulfide linkages.
analysis: Insulin is a hormone produced by the beta cells of the pancreas, not the alpha cells, which produce glucagon. The structure of insulin consists of two polypeptide chains (A and B) that are linked by disulfide bonds, making option opb correct. Insulin does not shift potassium outside the cell; rather, it facilitates the uptake of potassium into cells, which invalidates option opc. The half-life of subcutaneous insulin is much shorter than 60 minutes, typically around 5-10 minutes, which makes option opd incorrect. Therefore, the only true statement regarding insulin is that it consists of two polypeptide chains bound by disulfide linkages, confirming option opb as the correct answer.
